Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Genetic and Anatomical Determinants of Olfaction
Award.AbstractNarration:
The sense of smell is the oldest of the vertebrate senses and yet it remains the least understood. In humans, it is often considered a less important sense than vision or hearing, and this may explain in part why research has lagged behind that of other senses. Nevertheless, scent detection is a fundamental sense in animals involved in food acquisition, spatial orientation and mating. The wide variation of the sense of smell in animals (from marine mammals with very limited abilities to keen-scented species such as dogs) is affected by anatomical differences and likely has a genetic basis, yet the mechanistic connections between anatomy, genetic variation, gene expression and scent detection are poorly understood. This project uses dogs as a model system to investigate the anatomy and genetics of scent detection. Many dog breeds, such as scent hounds, have been strongly selected for an enhanced sense of smell, whereas other breeds, such as sight hounds, have been selected for visual acuity and are likely to have diminished ability to smell. Other canines, such as short-faced breeds, have impaired breathing and airflow across the nasal passage, which likely affects their sense of smell. Consequently, domestic dogs present a unique long-term experiment in scent detection and provide a range of sensory variation not found within any other mammal species. The results will uncover the mechanisms that enhance or lessen the sense of smell in animals and may allow for predictions of sensory function in a specific ecological context. Further, the results may lead to new biomedical insights for human health and impairments in the sense of smell.

In this project, the full sequence of the canine olfactory repertoire, which includes 1178 olfactory receptor genes, coupled with an analysis of gene expression will be undertaken in about 400 dogs from 26 breeds of varying olfactory ability. The genes will be sequenced using a capture array designed from existing complete genome sequences and the sequencing of gene transcripts (RNA-seq) will be based on olfactory tissue samples. This genetic information will complement anatomical and functional analyses of 66 dogs from the same breeds using high-resolution CT scans that will facilitate reconstruction of the olfactory organ, which will be analyzed and correlated with indices of olfactory sensitivity and olfactory gene repertoire diversity. Computational fluid dynamics simulations of airflow and odorant deposition in anatomically accurate reconstructions of the nasal cavity will be compared across these breeds to determine if the nasal anatomy and architecture of some dogs directs more odorant-laden airflow to the olfactory region of the nose. Anatomical, genomic and expression data will be available on the program website or submitted to public databases (e.g. DigiMorph or Genbank).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Olfaction, or the sense of smell, is the oldest of vertebrate (animals with backbones) special senses and yet it remains the least well understood.  Some mammals are considered to be excellent sniffers, such as dogs, whereas others, such as cats are thought to be less adept. Previous studies have revealed marked differences in olfactory anatomy and the number of olfactory genes between species with a poor sense of smell, such as marine mammals (sea lions, seals) and those with more enhanced olfactory ability, such as most terrestrial mammals.  However, it has been more difficult to distinguish olfactory specialists among the terrestrial mammal species. Using dogs as a model system, we conducted a novel cross-disciplinary project that investigated possible links between olfactory ability and anatomy, genetic factors, gene expression, and gene regulation. Many dog breeds, such as scent hounds (e.g. bloodhound), have been strongly selected for enhanced olfactory ability, whereas other breeds, such as sight hounds (e.g. borzoi), have been selected for visual acuity and are likely to have diminished olfactory ability. Other canines, such as short-faced breeds (e.g. pugs), have impaired breathing and airflow across the nasal epithelium, which likely also affects olfactory acuity. Consequently, domestic dogs present a unique long-term experiment in olfaction and provide a range of olfactory variation not found within any other mammal species.

The fundamental question we wished to answer was whether there are signals of olfactory ability in aspects of the nasal anatomy and/or genes of dogs.  Because dogs play a central role in critical detection tasks, such as drug, disease, and explosive detection, as well as human rescue, the discovery of a feature or set of features that signal enhanced olfactory ability in dogs would be welcome. We explored the anatomy of olfaction with CT scans of over 100 dog skulls from 45 breeds, all from museum collections.  We focused on one structure, the cribriform plate (CP), that separates the olfactory bulb of the brain from the nasal chamber (Fig. 1). The CP was virtually dissected from the skull and its surface area and other features were quantified. Previous work across a wide array of mammal species showed that the size of the CP was correlated with olfactory ability and olfactory genome size. Thus, we expected that breeds known for their sniffing talents would have relatively large CP. They did not. Although the size and shape of the CP varied greatly among breeds, there was no association between these two features and putative scent ability (Fig. 2A). Instead CP shape was predicted more by overall skull shape with short-faced breeds having very flat CP relative to other breeds. We did find that all dogs have relatively smaller CP than their ancestor, the gray wolf, suggesting there has been a loss of olfactory capacity due to domestication (Fig. 2B).

To uncover how olfactory ability is determined by genetic differences, we assessed genomic variation in the entire olfactory receptor (OR) array of 800+ genes in over 60 dog breeds, and on a limited subset, we also quantified gene expression to assess regulatory variation that may correlate with olfactory function.  Surprisingly, we found that the number of functional OR genes within or across breeds was not predictive of putative olfactory ability. In addition, gene expression analysis did not find any olfactory receptors associated with scenting ability in dogs, but did recover a significant association between some olfactory receptors’ expression and body size in dogs.

In terms of downstream impacts, many of the approaches we have pioneered, such as anatomical characterization of a sensory system and flow-based models of olfaction can be applied to other systems where anatomical structures and airflow impact functions such as respiration, locomotion, temperature and water regulation. In addition, our study has produced over 5,000 CT slices of the skulls of 45 breeds of domestic dog. All of the CT scans will be made available in the public domain within the next four years. In addition, data from over 800 olfactory receptor genes found in over 100 dogs breeds as well as gene expression data on olfactory epithelial tissue of 24 dogs from 10 dog breeds were placed in the public domain (via dbSNP, GenBank, RefSeq, and SRA public databases). The olfactory receptors are challenging to annotate so our new database will add materially to existing information.  At UCLA, four postdocs (three women), three graduate students (all women) and seven undergraduates (three women) were trained in aspects of anatomy, genetics, and computer visualization as part of this project.  Two Ph.D. dissertations were derived from data retrieved by this grant.  Of the seven undergraduate students who participated in the work, three were women, one was LatinX and one was LGBT. Among the undergraduates, three have gone on to graduate or professional school in biology.
